question: Question_04_(d)
statement:
The following discrete dynamical system describes the yearly migration
of wild horse populations among three areas R, G, and B. Let
\emph{r(t)}, \emph{g(t)}, and \emph{b(t)} be the sizes of the horse
population in areas R, G, and B respectively at the
\emph{t\textsuperscript{th}} year.

\begin{align*}
x(t+1) &= \begin{bmatrix} r(t+1) \\ g(t+1) \\ b(t+1) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/3 \\
r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/2 \\
g(t)/3 + b(t)/6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/3 \\ 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/2 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 1/6 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} r(t) \\ g(t) \\ b(t) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= Ax(t)\end{align*}

Where the Markov matrix \emph{A} describes how the horses move among
these areas from one year to the next. The 1st column indicates that
each year 1/2 of the horses in area R remain in area R and 1/2 will
migrate to area G. The 2nd column shows that horses in area G will be
evenly distributed in the three areas one year later. The 3rd column
implies that, of the horses in area B, 1/3 will migrate to area R, 1/2
will migrate to area G, and only 1/6 will remain in area B.

We assume that no horses are lost and no new horses are added and that
initially (i.e. at \emph{t = 0}), there are a total of 350 horses all
located in area B. Thus $\vec x(0) = [0\ 0\ 350]^T$.

\textbf{(d)} Find $\vec x(t)$ in terms of the eigenvalues and
eigenvectors of \emph{A}. Then, calculate
$\lim_{t \to \infty} \vec x(t)$.
sols:
For this problem we want to find $x(t)$. We know that
$x(0) = \left[ \begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 0 \\ 350 \end{array} \right]$. And
$x_{(1)} = Ax_{(0)}$. We can generalize to the form
$x_{(n)} = Ax_{(n-1)}$ This can further be generalized to
$x_{(n)} = A^{n}x_{(0)}$

From part c we found that $S^{-1}AS = \Lambda$. We can rearrange this to
$A = S\Lambda S^{-1}$. So
$A^{n} = (S\Lambda S^{-1})^{n} = S\Lambda^{n}S^{-1}$ because $S$ and
$S^{-1}$ will cancel each other out.

This means we can easily find
$\lim_{n \to \infty}x_{n} = A^{n}x_{0} = S\Lambda^{n}S^{-1}x_{0}$ Recall
that two of our eigenvalues were less than zero so when we take this
limit they will go to zero.

$\lim_{n \to \infty}x_{n} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \frac{2}{5} & -\frac{1}{2} & 0 \\ \frac{3}{7} & 0 & -\frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{6}{35} & \frac{1}{2} & \frac{1}{2} \end{array} \right]$$\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 &0 & 0 \end{array} \right]$
$\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} \frac{2}{5} & -\frac{1}{2} & 0 \\ \frac{3}{7} & 0 & -\frac{1}{2} \\ \frac{6}{35} & \frac{1}{2} & \frac{1}{2} \end{array} \right]^{-1}$
$\left[ \begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 0 \\ 350 \end{array} \right]$

Once we do this we find the answer
$x_{n} =\left[ \begin{array}{c} 140\\ 150\\ 60 \end{array} \right]$
